conclusion: To solve the problem, we need to determine the speed v_b of rod b when the speed of rod a is v_a = 1.0 m/s. We will use the principles of electromagnetism, energy conservation, and Newton's laws.

premise: When rod a moves with velocity v_a, it cuts the magnetic field lines, inducing an emf in the circuit.
conclusion: The induced emf \( \mathcal{E} \) is given by: \( \mathcal{E} = B L v_a \)

premise: The total resistance R_{\text{total}} of the circuit is the sum of the resistances of rods a and b.

conclusion: The current \( I \) in the circuit is: \( I = \frac{\mathcal{E}}{R_{\text{total}}} = \frac{0.1 \, \text{V}}{0.2 \, \Omega} = 0.5 \, \text{A} \)

premise: The current I in the circuit is 0.5 A.
conclusion: The Ampere force \( F_a \) on rod a is: \( F_a = B I L = (0.2 \, \text{T}) \times (0.5 \, \text{A}) \times (0.5 \, \text{m}) = 0.05 \, \text{N} \)

premise: The same current flows through both rods.
conclusion: The Ampere force \( F_b \) on rod b is also: \( F_b = B I L = 0.05 \, \text{N} \)

premise: Rod a experiences the following forces: Applied force F = 2 N upward along the incline, Gravitational force component m_a g \sin \theta downward along the incline, Ampere force F_a downward along the incline.
conclusion: The net force \( F_{\text{net}, a} \) on rod a is: \( F_{\text{net}, a} = F - m_a g \sin \theta - F_a \)

premise: \( F_{\text{net}, a} = F - m_a g \sin \theta - F_a \)
